pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naḷeru’s Nimba tree with a large sangha of five hundred monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.2: And a brahmin in Verañjā was told:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.3: “Sir, the ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, is staying at Verañjā at the foot of Naleru’s Nimba tree with a large sangha of five hundred monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.4: That Buddha Gotama has a good reputation:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.5: ‘He is indeed a Master, perfected and fully awakened, complete in insight and conduct, happy, knower of the world, supreme trainer of tamable people, teacher of gods and humans, the Master, the Buddha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.6: With his own insight he has seen this world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, and he makes it known to others.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.7: He has a Teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end. It has a true goal and is well articulated. He sets out a perfectly complete and pure spiritual life.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.1.8: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.1: Then that brahmin went to the Buddha, exchanged pleasantries with him, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.3: that you don’t bow down to old brahmins, stand up for them, or offer them a seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.4: Now I’ve seen that this is indeed the case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.6: “Brahmin, in the world with its gods, its lords of death, and its supreme beings, in this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans, I don’t see anyone to whom I should bow down, for whom I should rise up, or to whom I should offer a seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.2.7: If I bowed down to anyone, rose up for him, or offered him a seat, his head would explode.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.2: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that the ascetic Gotama lacks taste.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.3: For the taste for forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and material objects has been abandoned by me, cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that it is incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.4: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.6: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m unlikeable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.7: For the liking of forms, sounds, smells, flavors, and material objects has been abandoned by the Buddha, cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that it is incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.8: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.10: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that the ascetic Gotama teaches non-action.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.11: For I teach the non-doing of misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.12: I teach the non-doing of various sorts of bad, unwholesome actions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.13: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.15: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that the ascetic Gotama is an annihilationist.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.16: For I speak of the annihilation of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.17: I speak of the annihilation of various sorts of bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.18: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.20: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I am detestable.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.21: For I detest misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.22: I detest being possessed of various sorts of bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.23: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.25: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m an exterminator.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.26: For I teach for the sake of the extermination of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.27: for the extermination of various sorts bad, unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.28: But that’s not what you meant.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.30: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m austere.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.31: For I say that bad, unwholesome qualities—misconduct by body, speech, and mind—are to be disciplined.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.32: He who has abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined, who has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm-stump, done away with them so utterly that they are incapable of reappearing—him I call one who is austere.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.33: Now I have abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined, have cut them off at the root, made them like a palm tree, done away with them so utterly that they are incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.34: But that’s not what you meant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.36: “There is a way one could rightly say about me that I’m withdrawn.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.37: For he whose future conception in a womb, whose rebirth in a future life, is abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that he is incapable of reappearing—him I call one who is withdrawn.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.38: Now my future conception in a womb, my rebirth in a future life, has been abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that I’m incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.3.39: But that’s not what you meant.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.1: Brahmin, suppose there were a hen with eight or ten or twelve eggs,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.2: which she had properly covered, properly warmed, and properly incubated.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.3: Is the first chick that hatches safely—after piercing through the egg-shell with its claw or its beak—to be called the eldest or the youngest?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.5: for he’s the eldest of those.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.6: “Just so, in this deluded population, enveloped like an egg, I alone in the world have split the eggshell of delusion and reached the supreme full awakening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.4.7: I, brahmin, am the world’s eldest and best.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.1: I was firmly energetic and had clarity of mindfulness; my body was tranquil and my mind unified.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.2: Fully secluded from the five senses, secluded from unwholesome mental qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which consists of joy and bliss born of seclusion and is accompanied by movement of the mind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.3: Through the stilling of the movement of the mind, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has internal confidence and unification of mind and consists of joy and bliss born of stillness.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.4: Through the fading away of joy, I remained even-minded, mindful, and fully aware, experiencing bliss directly, and I entered and remained in the third absorption of which the noble ones declare:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.5: ‘One is even-minded, mindful, and abides in bliss.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.5.6: Through the abandoning of bliss and suffering and the earlier ending of joy and aversion, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, which has neither suffering nor happiness and consists of purity of mindfulness and even-mindedness.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.1: Then, with my mind collected, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, soft, wieldy, steady, and imperturbable, I directed it to the knowledge which is the recollection of former lives.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.2: I recollected many past lives, that is,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.3: one birth, two births, three births, four births, five births, ten births, twenty births, thirty births, forty births, fifty births, a hundred births, a thousand births, a hundred thousand births, and many eons of world dissolution, many eons of world evolution, and many eons of both dissolution and evolution, and I knew:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.4: ʻThere I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.5: Passing away from there, I was reborn elsewhere,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.6: and there I had such a name, such a family, such appearance, such food, such experience of happiness and suffering, and such a life-span.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.7: Passing away from there, I was reborn here.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.8: In this way I recollected many past lives with their characteristics and particulars.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.9: This was the first true insight attained by me in the first part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.10: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.11: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.6.12: This, brahmin, was my first breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.1: Then, with my mind collected, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, soft, wieldy, steady, and imperturbable, I directed it to the knowledge of the arising and passing away of beings.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.2: With superhuman and purified clairvoyance, I saw beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and I understood how beings pass on according to their actions:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.3: ‘These beings who engaged in misconduct by body, speech, and mind, who abused the noble ones, who had wrong views and acted accordingly,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.4: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a lower realm, a bad destination, a world of misery, hell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.5: But these beings who engaged in good conduct of body, speech, and mind, who did not abuse the noble ones, who held right view and acted accordingly,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.6: at the breaking up of the body after death, have been reborn in a good destination, a heaven world.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.7: In this way, with superhuman and purified clairvoyance, I saw beings passing away and getting reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, gone to good destinations and to bad destinations, and I understood how beings pass on according to their actions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.8: This was the second true insight attained by me in the middle part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.9: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.10: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.7.11: This, brahmin, was my second breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.1: Then, with my mind collected, purified, cleansed, flawless, free from defilements, soft, wieldy, steady, and imperturbable, I directed it to the knowledge of the ending of the corruptions.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.2: I knew according to reality: ʻThis is suffering;’ ʻThis is the origin of suffering;’ ʻThis is the end of suffering;’ ʻThis is the path leading to the end of suffering.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.3: I knew according to reality: ʻThese are the corruptions;’ ʻThis is the origin of the corruptions;’ ʻThis is the end of the corruptions;’ ʻThis is the path leading to the end of the corruptions.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.4: When I knew and saw this, my mind was freed from the corruption of sensual desire, from the corruption of existence, from the corruption of views, and from the corruption of delusion.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.5: When it was freed, I knew it was freed,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.6: and I understood that birth had come to an end, the spiritual life had been lived, the job had been done, there was no further state of existence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.7: This was the third true insight attained by me in the last part of the night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.8: Delusion was dispelled and true insight arose, darkness was dispelled and light arose,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.9: as happens to one who remains heedful, energetic, and diligent.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.8.10: This, brahmin, was my third breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.1: That brahmin then said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.2: “Good Gotama is the eldest; good Gotama is the best!
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.4: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what had been hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what’s there—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.5: just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.6: Good Gotama, I go for refuge to you, and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.7: Please accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.8: And please consent to spend the rainy-season residence at Verañjā together with the Order of monks.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.9: The Buddha consented by keeping silent, and the brahmin understood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:1.9.10: He then got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.1: At that time Verañjā was short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw. It was not easy to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.2: Just then some horse-dealers from Uttarāpatha had entered the rainy-season residence at Verañjā with five hundred horses.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.3: In the horse-pen they prepared many portions of steamed grain for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.4: Then, after robing up in the morning, the monks took their bowls and robes and entered Verañjā for alms. Being unable to obtain anything, they went to the horse-pen. They then brought the portions of steamed grain back to the monastery, pounded them, and ate them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.5: Venerable Ānanda crushed a portion of steamed grain on a stone, took it to the Buddha, and the Buddha ate it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.6: The Buddha heard the sound of the mortar.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.7: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.8: they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.9: Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.10: Buddhas have destroyed access to what is unbeneficial.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.11: Buddhas question the monks for two reasons: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.12: And so the Buddha said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, what’s this sound of a mortar?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.13: Ānanda told him what was happening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.1.15: You who are superior people have conquered the problems of famine; later generations will despise even rice and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.1: Then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.2: “At present, Venerable Sir, Verañjā is short of food and afflicted with hunger, with crops affected by whiteheads and turned to straw.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.3: It’s not easy to get by almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.4: Sir, the under-surface of this great earth is abounding with food, which tastes just like pure honey.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.5: It would be good if I inverted the earth so that the monks may enjoy the nutrition in the sprouts.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.6: “But what will you do, Moggallāna, with those creatures who are living there?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.7: “I will transform one of my hands to be just like the great earth, and I’ll make those creatures go there.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.8: Then with the other hand I’ll invert the earth.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.9: “Let it be, Moggallāna, please don’t invert the earth.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.10: Those creatures might lose their minds.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.11: “In that case, Sir, it would be good if the whole Sangha of monks could go to Uttarakuru for alms.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:2.2.12: “Let it be, Moggallāna, please don’t pursue this.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.1: At this time, while Venerable Sāriputta was in seclusion, he thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.2: “For which Buddhas did the spiritual life not last long?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.3: For which Buddhas did the spiritual life last long?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.4: In the evening, after coming out of seclusion, Sāriputta approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.5: “Just now, Sir, while I was in seclusion, I thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.6: ‘For which Buddhas did the spiritual life not last long, and for which ones did it last long?’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.7: “Sāriputta, the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū didn’t last long.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.1.8: But the spiritual life established by Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa did last long.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.1: “And what’s the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū didn’t last long?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.2: “Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū were disinclined to give detailed teachings to their disciples.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.3: They gave few discourses in prose and in prose and verse, few expositions, verses, inspired exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.4: and they didn’t lay down training rules or recite a monastic code.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.5: After the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, clans, and social standing, who had gone forth from various families—allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.6: It’s just like flowers not tied with a string to a wooden plank: they’re scattered about, whirled about, and destroyed by the wind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.8: Because they’re not held together by a string.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.9: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples allowed that spiritual life to disappear rapidly.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.10: But those Buddhas were untiring in instructing their disciples after reading their minds.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.11: At one time, Sāriputta, while staying in a certain frightening forest grove, Buddha Vessabhū, the Perfected and the fully Awakened One, instructed an sangha of a thousand monks, reading their minds and saying,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.13: pay attention like this, not like this;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.14: abandon this; having attained this, abide in it.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.15: When those thousand monks had been instructed by Buddha Vessabhū, their minds were freed from the corruptions without grasping.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.16: But when anyone with sensual desire entered that frightening forest grove, usually their hair would stand on end.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.2.17: This is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Vipassī, Buddha Sikhī, and Buddha Vessabhū didn’t last long.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.1: “What then is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa lasted long?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.2: “Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa were diligent in giving detailed teachings to their disciples.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.3: They gave many discourses in prose and in prose and verse, many expositions, verses, inspired exclamations, quotations, birth stories, amazing accounts, and analyses;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.4: and they laid down training rules and recited a monastic code.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.5: After the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples—of various names, clans, and social standing, who had gone forth from various families—made that spiritual life last for a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.6: It’s just like flowers tied with a string to a wooden plank: they are not scattered about, whirled about, or destroyed by the wind.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.8: Because they are held together by a string.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.9: Just so, after the disappearance of those Buddhas, after the disappearance of the disciples awakened under them, those who were the last disciples made that spiritual life last for a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.3.10: This is the reason why the spiritual life established by Buddha Kakusandha, Buddha Konāgamana, and Buddha Kassapa lasted long.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.1: Then Sāriputta got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, put the palms of his hands together, and said,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.2: “This is the right time, Venerable Sir,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.3: for laying down training rules and reciting a monastic code, so that this spiritual life may last for a long time.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.5: the Buddha will know the right time for that.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.6: The Teacher doesn’t lay down training rules and recite a monastic code until the causes of corruption appear in the Sangha.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.7: And they don’t appear until the Sangha has attained long standing,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.11: an abundance of the best material support,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.14: When this happens, then the Teacher lays down training rules for his disciples and recites a monastic code in order to hold back those causes of corruption.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.15: Sāriputta, the Sangha of monks is devoid of immorality, devoid of danger, stainless, pure, established in the essence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:3.4.16: Even the least developed of these five hundred monks is a stream-enterer, not subject to rebirth in the lower world, fixed in destiny, bound for awakening.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.1: Then the Buddha said to Ānanda, “Ānanda, it’s the custom for Buddhas not to go wandering in the country without taking leave of those who invited them to spend the rainy-season residence.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.2: Let’s go to the brahmin of Verañjā and take leave.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.4: The Buddha robed up, took his bowl and robe and, with Ānanda as his attendant, went to that brahmin’s house where he sat down on the prepared seat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pj1:4.5: The brahmin approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
